awd_titl_txt: 2022 Photonuclear Reactions: Frontiers in Nuclear and Hadronic Physics GRC will be held at the Holderness School in Holderness, New Hampshire, August 7 – 12, 2022.
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for students to participate in the 2022 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on “Photonuclear Reactions: Frontiers in Nuclear and Hadronic Physics GRC”, which will be held at the Holderness School in Holderness, NH, August 7 – 12, 2022.  These meetings bring together scientists from around the world to focus on research at the forefront of photonuclear reactions. The conference is organized in a way to promote significant discussion and time for collaboration throughout the week. 

This award will provide partial support for a limited number of junior researchers to attend the 2022 GRC. The support for the participants will be selected by the chairs based on submitted abstracts of their research. This support will allow participants to attend these meetings who may otherwise not be able to attend. Participation of young researchers in these meetings plays a large role in the development of the future leaders of nuclear science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The awarded NSF funds, totaling $6000, were entirely spent to support participation of young scientists: postdocs and graduate students. In detail, we awarded registration discounts to the following 12 young researchers, each of them receiving a $500 registration waiver from NSF funds. 

The conference has been by many metrics a success. We received 165 applications and had 135 registered participants (3 registered attendees had to cancel during the meeting).

  • 80% of the participants listed countries of travel origin as the United States and 20% listed Europe and Israel. The strict travel regulations and difficulties in visa applications in Asian countries made it impossible for us to recruit in-person participants. 

  • 38% (32%) of our speakers (total attendees) were female and non-binary scientists.

  • 62% of our participants were young scientists (students or postdocs). Among them, 15 spoke in the plenary session. We had a total of 45 speakers.

  • We had more than 60 poster submissions and could only select the 60 posters due to the GRC site space limitations; we reserved most of the poster spots for young scientists.   

We received positive evaluations, both in the official survey and in many private communications. Among the 86% of the participants who filled out the GRC survey form, when asked "Select no more than two statements which best describe the most valuable aspects of the conference.", more than 57% checked "There were ample opportunities for networking between junior and senior scientists, creating a welcoming environment", 33% for "Scientific content was cutting edge", 28% for "The environment was respectful and collegial". Similar positive evaluation throughout different categories of the GRC survey. The overall satisfaction rating is 80%.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2023
Modified by: Huey-Wen Lin

The conference has been by many metrics a success. We received 165 applications and had 135 registered participants (3 registered attendees had to cancel during the meeting).


80% of the participants listed countries of travel origin as the United States and 20% listed Europe and Israel. The strict travel regulations and difficulties in visa applications in Asian countries made it impossible for us to recruit in-person participants. 


38% (32%) of our speakers (total attendees) were female and non-binary scientists.


62% of our participants were young scientists (students or postdocs). Among them, 15 spoke in the plenary session. We had a total of 45 speakers.




We had more than 60 poster submissions and could only select the 60 posters due to the GRC site space limitations; we reserved most of the poster spots for young scientists.   


We received positive evaluations, both in the official survey and in many private communications. Among the 86% of the participants who filled out the GRC survey form, when asked "Select no more than two statements which best describe the most valuable aspects of the conference.", more than 57% checked "There were ample opportunities for networking between junior and senior scientists, creating a welcoming environment", 33% for "Scientific content was cutting edge", 28% for "The environment was respectful and collegial". Similar positive evaluation throughout different categories of the GRC survey. The overall satisfaction rating is 80%.
